title: General
description: General packinghouse requirements including chemical storage and labeling, proper use of food-grade chemicals, Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) signage, and food defense controls

requirements.text: Are all chemicals (pesticides, sanitizers, detergents, lubricants, etc.) stored securely, safely and are they labeled correctly?
mandatoryStatements: All chemicals including pesticides, sanitizers, detergents, and lubricants must be stored securely in designated areas
Chemical storage areas must be designed to contain spills and leaks with adequate ventilation
All chemical containers must maintain original labels or have equivalent labeling
Safety Data Sheets (SDS) must be available for all chemicals
Emergency response equipment must be readily available near chemical storage areas
Regular inspections of chemical storage areas must be conducted
Chemicals must be stored away from food products, ingredients, and packaging materials
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly inspection of chemical storage areas verifying secure storage, proper labeling, SDS availability, and compliance with safety requirements
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily visual verification that chemical storage areas are secure and chemicals are properly labeled, immediate action for any unlabeled or improperly stored chemicals

requirements.text: Are "food grade" and "non-food grade" chemicals used appropriately, according to the label and not commingled?
mandatoryStatements: Food grade chemicals must be clearly separated from non-food grade chemicals
Chemicals must be used only according to manufacturer label instructions
Physical barriers must separate food grade and non-food grade chemical storage
Chemical application must follow approved procedures and concentrations
Only approved food-grade chemicals may be used on food contact surfaces
Chemical segregation must be maintained during storage and use
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly audit of chemical segregation practices, verification that only food-grade chemicals are used in food contact applications
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly verification of chemical segregation, daily monitoring of chemical application procedures and concentrations

requirements.text: Are signs supporting GMPs posted appropriately?
mandatoryStatements: GMP signage must be prominently displayed in appropriate areas throughout the facility
Signs must be posted at entry areas, handwashing stations, and toilet facilities
Signage must include multilingual content as needed for workforce
Signs must be visible, legible, and maintained in good condition
GMP reminders must address hygiene and safety requirements
Signage must be replaced when faded, damaged, or illegible
requirements.verificationExpectations: Semi-annual inspection of GMP signage for completeness, visibility, and condition with replacement of damaged signs
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Quarterly verification that GMP signage is present in all required locations and remains visible and legible

requirements.text: Are the necessary food defense controls implemented in the operation?
mandatoryStatements: Food defense controls must be implemented to prevent intentional contamination
Access control procedures must restrict unauthorized entry to production areas
Visitor management system must include sign-in requirements and escorts
Food defense vulnerability assessments must be conducted and documented
Security measures must address identified vulnerabilities
Employee background checks or screening must be appropriate to risk level
Corrective actions must be implemented for identified food defense weaknesses
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual food defense vulnerability assessment and review of security measures, quarterly verification of access control compliance
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily monitoring of visitor logs and access control compliance, immediate response to security incidents or unauthorized access

mandatoryStatements: All chemicals including pesticides, sanitizers, detergents, and lubricants must be stored securely in designated areas with proper labeling indicating contents, hazards, and usage instructions
Food grade chemicals must be clearly separated from non-food grade chemicals to prevent cross-contamination and used only according to manufacturer label instructions
Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) signage must be prominently displayed in appropriate areas throughout the facility to remind workers of hygiene and safety requirements
Food defense controls must be implemented to prevent intentional contamination or adulteration of food products through access control, visitor management, and security measures
Chemical storage areas must be designed to contain spills and leaks with adequate ventilation and emergency response equipment readily available
All chemical containers must maintain original labels or have equivalent labeling that includes Safety Data Sheets (SDS) and usage concentrations
Facility management must conduct regular inspections of chemical storage areas to verify compliance with safety and segregation requirements
Food defense vulnerability assessments must be conducted and documented with corrective actions implemented for identified weaknesses
capaInject: Establish a comprehensive chemical inventory management system with designated storage locations, labeling requirements, and regular inspection schedules
Implement a chemical segregation procedure that physically separates food grade from non-food grade chemicals using locked cabinets, separate rooms, or clearly marked zones
Develop and post GMP reminder signs at critical control points including entry areas, handwashing stations, toilet facilities, and production zones with multilingual content as needed
Create a food defense plan that includes access control procedures, visitor sign-in requirements, security camera coverage, and employee background check policies
When chemical labeling violations are found, immediately remove mislabeled or unlabeled chemicals from use, properly label or dispose of them, and retrain personnel on chemical handling procedures
If food grade and non-food grade chemicals are found commingled, immediately segregate them, assess risk of contamination, and implement physical barriers to prevent future occurrences
Establish a preventive maintenance schedule for GMP signage to replace faded, damaged, or missing signs and verify visibility and comprehension during worker training sessions
Conduct annual food defense vulnerability assessments and update security measures based on findings, regulatory changes, and industry best practices
traceabilityInject: Maintain a master chemical inventory log documenting all chemicals on-site including product name, supplier, receipt date, storage location, and SDS availability
Document chemical segregation inspections with date, inspector name, findings, and corrective actions taken for any non-conformances
Keep records of GMP signage installation and maintenance including sign location, language(s), installation date, and replacement schedule
Maintain food defense logs documenting visitor access, employee badge issuance, security incidents, vulnerability assessments, and corrective action implementation
Retain chemical usage logs for cleaning and sanitation chemicals showing dilution rates, application areas, frequency, and personnel performing the activities
Document employee training records on chemical handling, GMP requirements, and food defense awareness with training dates, topics covered, and verification of understanding
Keep receiving records for all chemicals including inspection for proper labeling, damage, and verification that only approved chemicals are accepted
Maintain correspondence with chemical suppliers including SDS updates, product reformulations, and regulatory compliance certificates
micro_inject: Improper chemical storage or use can result in direct contamination of food products with toxic substances leading to serious public health consequences and product recalls
Non-food grade chemicals used inappropriately on food contact surfaces can leave residues that harbor pathogenic bacteria including Listeria monocytogenes, Salmonella, and E. coli
GMP signage serves as a critical reminder system to prevent behavioral contamination vectors such as improper handwashing which can transfer pathogens from workers to products
Food defense controls prevent intentional adulteration with biological, chemical, or physical contaminants that could cause widespread illness or death in the consuming population
Chemical cross-contamination between food grade and non-food grade products can introduce antimicrobial-resistant bacteria or chemical residues that compromise food safety
Proper chemical segregation prevents accidental use of toxic substances in food production areas where they could come into contact with products, ingredients, or food contact surfaces
Food defense vulnerabilities create opportunities for intentional introduction of pathogens or toxins by disgruntled employees, terrorists, or other malicious actors
Effective GMP implementation supported by visible signage reduces the likelihood of cross-contamination events that can introduce allergens, pathogens, or foreign materials into finished products
